El se dedica a las actividades agropecuarias  y al comercio de ganado, cerdos, caballos; dicho trabajo lo aprendió  de sus padres, lo cual lo realiza desde hace 22 años.  Solicita un crédito que lo invertirá en la compra de 4 silos metálicos para guardar maíz y el resto en la compra de cerdos.
Esta inversión le será de  mucha utilidad, ya que podrá tener el maíz guardado y sacarlo a la venta cuando el precio de este mejore. El Riesgo que se puede tener es una plaga en el maíz y se pueda dañar. Su objetivo es seguir luchando para mejorar sus condiciones de vida personal y familiar, crear un negocio más rentable, que le permita incrementar sus ingresos económicos, para aportar a sus hijos con el estudio y alimentación.
texts.en:
Felipe raises and sells cows, pigs, horses and grain crops.  He lives with his wife, with whom he has four children aged 1, 6, 10 and 12.  Three of them are in school and depend on him, while the other child is living in a foreign country.

He learned the business of farming from his parents, and he has been doing this work for 22 years.  He is seeking a loan to invest in four metal silos for storing corn.  He will use the rest for the purchase of pigs.

This investment will be very useful, since he will be able to store his corn and take it to the market when the price is better.  A possible risk is that the corn could be suffer crop disease and become damaged.  

Felipe's goal is to continue fighting to improve his family's standard of living, and to create a more profitable business.  This will enable him to increase his income so that he can feed and educate his children.

loans.use: to buy pigs and four metal silos.

loans.name: Katamakisi Group

texts.en:
Katamakisi is a group of 17 farmers in Teso District, represented by Celestine. The group has 12 women and 5 men. Celestine is on the right of the photo, with her hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to her on credit, consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of sweet potato, millet and sorghum. Celestine first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and use increased profits to send her children to school.

Celestine described her harvest as very good last year, but she believes she can have an even better one this year. She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send her children to school and repair her home. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Katamakisi Group will receive 8.5 acres' worth of inputs, on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potato, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a charcoal seller from the Kawempe-Kihindi zone who stays in Kyebando, a slum area in the city's outskirts. 

She started a charcoal business way back in 1993 to earn a living to pay tuition fees for her five children and construct some rental units. She started the business after losing her husband to generate some income and support her family with a better welfare. She also wanted to serve the low- and middle-income earners who cannot afford the high cost of gas and electricity.

She wants a loan of 1,500,000 shillings to buy more sacks of charcoal and boost her business. The income will help her improve her standards of living and those of her children. She is a hardworking woman.

Sarah is pictured with a UGAFODE staff member at her business during an appraisal.

loans.use: To buy charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy scrap for her husband's scrap-selling business.

loans.name: Minda

texts.en: Minda earns a living by running her sari-sari (variety) store, selling various goods to the people in her place.She has been in the business for more than a year.  Minda is asking for a loan to buy more goods to sell, like canned goods, candies, biscuits and chips, soap and toiletries. With this, she will be able to attract and cater to more buyers in her store. In the future, Minda has hopes of making her business a success and sustainable.

loans.use: to buy more goods to sell, like canned goods, candies, biscuits and chips, soap and toiletries

loans.name: Tuungane Group

texts.en:
Tuungane Group is located in Webuye District. It is a group of 14 women and 2 men led by Rabecca, pictured on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of sweet potato, millet, and sorghum cultivation. Rabecca first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Rabecca joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer, and also because their group work makes working easier.

Rabecca described her harvest as very good last year, but she believes she can have an even better one this year. She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school and, perhaps, buy some more land for farming. Tuungane Group members will each receive input loans of ½ acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total, they will receive inputs for 8 acres of sweet potato, millet and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potato, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Dunia

texts.en:
Dunia is a 24-year-old, single woman who has been working as a hairdresser since 2008. In 2011, Dunia moved her business outside of her house to make sure that her customers will be more relaxed and because she needs to develop her business to increase her income.

Dunia is a three cycles loan borrower from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development. Through her previous loans, she was able to buy the necessary tools and machines she needs to move, expand, and develop her business. 

Through this youth loan she has applied for, Dunia will make necessary maintenance and add decorations to her beauty salon, in addition to buying new closets and doors.

Dunia is very excited for this loan because she will be able to make her salon comfortable and attractive, which will pamper her customers in a very special way.

loans.use: to make necessary maintenance and add decorations to her salon.

loans.name: Kangombe's Group

texts.en: Kang'ombe is a sixty-five year old widow, having lost two husbands. She takes on jobs, such as working on other people's farms and burning charcoal, to earn money for her family -- however, farming is seasonal work. Kang'ombe is joining the KOMAZA microforestry program, so that she can build her dream house with the profits from her tree farm.

loans.use: to pay for eucalyptus seedlings, fertilizer, training and plantation maintenance support

loans.name: Baraka Group

texts.en:
Baraka Group has 18 farmers and is located in Webuye District. The group is represented by John, pictured on the right of Baraka Group with his hand raised. There are 6 men and 12 women in the group. John will receive input loans capable of planting ½ an acre with sorghum, millet, and sweet potato. John joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. He joined One Acre Fund so that he could grow enough food for the family and use increased profits to send his children to school.

John described his harvest as very good last year, but he believes he can have an even better one this year. He plans on using future profits from the harvest to send his children to school and, perhaps, save for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre's worth of agricultural inputs on credit. Baraka Group will receive 9 acres' worth of inputs, on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potato, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Tamar

texts.en:
Tamar is 44 years old. She lives in Samtredia District with her husband, retired father-in-law, and son, who is going to school. Tamar requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected each time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

Tamar is a teacher. She teaches math at the local school and also has private students. Her husband is working at the railway station, and they both get small monthly salaries.
 
Recently, Tamar requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Credo approved her loan request, in the frame of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The Start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and restart-up credits with soft conditions, to rural poor people who do not have access to other credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income.

With the received credit, Tamar will start trading in second-hand clothing. She will buy at the wholesale prices and resell with price mark-ups, among her fellow villagers. Tamar hopes that this business will be profitable, and that she will be able to use part of the profit for reinvesting in the business and another part for providing better living conditions for her family.

loans.use: To start trading in second-hand clothing

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy sandals and different shoes for women and men

loans.name: Ann. Maa Bhuyani Self Help Group

texts.en:
Ann. Maa Bhuyani Self Help Group is a group consisting of 14 members, all of whom are women. These entrepreneurs are very humble, hardworking and responsible people with good manners and lots of enthusiasm to improve their lives. A few years back, they all were facing the same kind of situation of poverty, so they planned to start a grocery shop where they can provide the basic household consumables to their customers. 

One of them is Mrs. Kamala, who was selected as their president. Kamala is a 40-year-old lady living with her husband and her two children, who are schooling. The lady in the navy blue saree standing fourth from the left-hand side is Kamala. 

Kamala’s husband works as a labourer in a factory situated near to her village. Kamala runs a grocery shop to help her husband financially. She sells rice, grains, lentils, edible oil, spices, biscuits, soap, detergent, hair oil, etc. in her shop. She has developed a very good relationship with her customers in the village. She likes the fact that she can cater to the needs of the people in her village. 

Kamala has a plan to make her shop bigger and keep multiple things in her shop to satisfy her customers. She also wants to purchase the items for her shop in bulk directly from the wholesalers, for which she has requested a loan to purchase items like toothbrushes, toothpaste, soft drinks, wheat flour, grains and other household consumables.

loans.use: to purchase rice, grains, lentils, edible oil, spices, biscuits, soap, detergent, hair oil, etc. for her grocery shop.

loans.name: Mealii

texts.en:
Mealii lives Changamwe area of Coast province. She is married and has five children, of whom four attend school. She owns a medical clinic, a business she has been operating for ten years now.

She learned about Milango through a friend, who invited her to the group. She joined the group with the aim of accessing credit to improve the operation of the business. The challenge she is facing is the effect of the high cost of living on the service.

Mealii is applying for a loan of 41,850 Kenyan shillings to buy medical supplies, like drugs, syringes, and so on. Her extra income from the loan will be added to her savings and used to pay school fees for her children. Her future plan is to open a referral hospital.

loans.use: To buy medical supplies, like drugs and syringes

loans.name: Sitha's Group

texts.en:
A resident from a rural village of the Thmor Koul district, Sitha is a 23-year-old mother of two children. The main sources of her family’s income are from rice farming on two-hectares of farmland and duck-raising, which she has been doing for five years. With her current business, she can earn about KHR 50,000 per day to spend for daily expenses. 

This is the seventh loan for Sitha with VisionFund Cambodia while the other member has been with VisionFund Cambodia for one cycle. Now Sitha is leading her group to apply for a loan of KHR 1,100,000 each. As the leader, she will use her portion to buy fertilizer and rice seeds for her farmland and use a portion of it to buy more ducks to raise. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her income, so as to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and rice seeds for her farmland and ducks to raise.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella is a 46 year old married woman. She has 3 children whose ages range from 14 to 23 years. She describes herself to be an optimistic and humble woman. She operates a retail stall where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for 4 years. Her business is located in a local residential area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the high price of clothes. She will use the Kes 30,000 loan to buy clothes to sell. Her business goal is to expand her business within 5 years. This is her third loan with SMEP DTM after taking a loan of Kes 30,000 which she managed to pay successfully. In addition, Stella works as a school teacher which adds to her income.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Getty Group

texts.en:
This group is made up of 3 partners, Getrude, Christiana and Mabel. They have been working together since 2012. They reside in the Dansoman community in Ghana. They trade in slippers, second hand clothes and herbal medicine.

Getrude is a 36 years old and married to Robert, a 44 year old business man. They are blessed with 2 children. She has been with ID Ghana for the past year and doing very well in her business.

She has been operating this business for 6 years. She is grateful to ID Ghana for the financial training she has received which has motivated her to save money in order to achieve her dream. 

This is her 2nd loan and she is requesting GHS 350 to buy more slippers to sell to her customers.  

The group needs a total amount of GHS 1,000 to buy more goods to sell to their customers in the community.

loans.use: To buy more slippers to sell.

loans.name: Neema Group

texts.en:
Timothy’s group has 15 farmer members and is located in the Webuye District of Kenya. Timothy is pictured on the right of Neema Group with his hand raised. Timothy is pictured amongst the 2 men and 13 women of his group. He will receive loans capable of planting ½ an acre with sorghum, millet, and sweet potatoes. Timothy joined the One Acre Fund during the Long Rains of 2010, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. Timothy joined the One Acre Fund so that he could grow enough food for his family and use the increased profits to send his children to school.

Timothy described his harvest as very good last year, but believes he can have an even better one this year. He plans on using the future profits from the harvest to send his children to school and repair his home. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Timothy’s group will receive 7.5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potatoes, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Margaritha

texts.en:
Margaritha, a 24 year old woman is married to Yan, who is 36 years old. They are blessed with 2 children: Dimar, 8, is in the 3rd grade of elementary school, and Gio is 6 months old.

Margaritha is running a food stall business. It is close to the bus station so her business is always crowded with customers. 

Margaritha intends to improve her business by adding different menu items. She has requested a loan of IDR 4,000,000 from TLM. She has planned to buy more rice, meat, vegetables, chicken etc. Margaritha hopes that TLM is willing to assist her in improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, meat, vegetables, etc

loans.name: Soery's Group

texts.en:
Living in a thatched roof house in a rural village of the Moung Russey district of Battambang province in Cambodia, Soery is 55 years old and married.

She and her husband have one son. She and her husband earn a living through rice farming and also through working for others for a fee and they have been in this business for 10 years. With her current business, she is able to earn approximately 14,000KHR per day to support her family.
 
This is the fifth loan for Soery with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. She has successfully paid back the past loans which have helped her better support her family with enough food. Now she is leading her group to ask for another loan of 1,000,000KHR each. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland and use a portion of it to spend on the labor costs in plowing her field. She hopes to increase her crop yield and sell it for a good price so as to improve her lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farmland

loans.name: Ing's Group

texts.en:
Ing, originally from Kror Kor district of Pursat province, is a widow and mother of five children. Currently, only two children are still under her dependency -- one of them is still in school and the other is too young for schooling. 

To deal with daily cost of living, Ing grows rice as the main source of her family’s income. She supplements her income via dessert-selling and a pig-raising business. With 16 years' involvement in the current business, she is able to earn up to KHR 19,900 per day.  

Including this cycle, she is a third-time borrower with VisionFund Cambodia (Kiva’s partner). She has repaid back her past loans wisely to upgrade her living, especially so she can buy a decent motorbike to support her living, as well as her business. 

Now, Ing forms a group of two to apply for a new loan with VisionFund Cambodia. As a group leader, she will use her loan portion to pay for plowing fees for her farmland. She greatly hopes that she can gain more yield and gain more income to improve her lifestyle.

loans.use: to pay for plowing fees for her farmland.

loans.name: Mariana

texts.es:
Mariana, surge la necesidad de optar por un nuevo préstamo ya que requiere comprar más mercadería para la tienda. Este le permitirá invertir en la adquisición de productos de la canasta básica, como lo son frijoles, arroz, azúcar, aceite, jabón entre otros.
Con el crédito anterior logro incrementar las utilidades e invirtió el dinero  en la compra de medicina para su compañero de vida, porque se encuentra enfermo. Las condiciones económicas han mejorado y ha fortalecido el inventario de su mercadería.
texts.en:
Mariana has decided to take a new loan, since she needs more merchandise for her store.  This will allow her to invest in grocery items such as beans, rice, sugar, oil, soap and other goods.

With her previous loan she was able to increase her profits, and she invested this money in medicine for her common-law husband, who is ill.  Her financial situation has improved, and she has re-stocked her store with merchandise.

loans.use: to buy beans, rice, sugar, oil, soap and other items.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe DANAYA sont essentiellement des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 42  ans,  3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygamiques à HAMDALLAYE un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso. 
Elles sont à leur quinzième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Les prêts antérieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
IVONE, au bout de la photo à droite,  fait la teinture à dans ce groupe de femmes DANAYA. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt des pagnes bazins, des colorants, des fils et de la soude caustique. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso ville.
Elle revend ses bazins teintés sur commande et fait ses prestations à domicile (Hamdallaye) un des quartiers populaires de la ville  de Sikasso. Sa clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30.000 FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The seven members of the group DANAYA are essentially married women who average 42 years of age and three children each living for the most part in polygamous families in HAMDALLAYE, a working-class district in Sikasso City. 

The women are on their 15th loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy customer need. The previous loans were correctly paid back. 

IVONE, at the far right in the photo, is the one who dyes cloth in this group. She intends to use her loan to purchase lengths of damask cloth, dyes, thread, and caustic soda. She gets her supplies from the big market in Sikasso City. 

She resells her dyed damasks by special order and provides such services at her home (Hamdallaye, a working-class district in Sikasso City). Her customer base is composed of men and women. 

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 30,000 francs CFA. Part of the profits is used to repay the loan with interest, and the other part is for savings.

loans.use: to purchase damask cloth, dyes, thread, and caustic soda

loans.name: Inyokha Group

texts.en:
Eunice is a member of the Inyokha Group in the Webuye District. She is pictured with 15 One Acre Fund farmers: 13 women and 2 men. Eunice is standing on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for a ½ acre of sweet potato, millet, and sorghum cultivation. Eunice joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012 and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. Eunice joined One Acre Fund so that she could gain access to hybrid seeds and fertilizer and the best input prices.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Eunice was only able to harvest 7 bags of maize per acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, she was able to harvest 18 bags per acre. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and repair her home. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Eunice’s group will receive 7.5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potato, millet, and sorghum

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: Susana earns a living through her food-vending business selling home-cooked snack foods to the people in her town. Susana is asking for a loan to buy additional ingredients like flour, butter, sugar, cooking oil, milk and other items. With this, she will be able to cook and sell more to the people in her town, thus augmenting her sales and income.

loans.use: To buy additional ingredients like flour, butter, sugar, cooking oil, milk and other items

loans.name: Akiba Group

texts.en:
Everline is pictured on the right with her hand raised amongst her Akiba Group members. The 19 of them, 11 women and 8 men, are farmers in Webuye District. 

Farming inputs, consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of sweet potatoes, millet, and sorghum, will be delivered to Everline on credit. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Everline’s first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year in order to rest assured of reliable input delivery and to be able to grow enough food for the family. 

Everline thought her harvest last year was poor. She hopes that, as a One Acre Fund farmer, she can have an excellent harvest. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and perhaps buy a cow. 

For the 2013 Long Rains season, Everline’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 9.5 acres of land.

The field officer is standing on the left in the photo.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potatoes, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Rida

texts.en: Rida, a 24-year-old married father of one, lives in Gaza where he has owned  a fruit and vegetables food stall since 2011. Rida has requested this youth loan from Ryada to buy a small automobile to reduce his transportation costs, allowing him to save more of his income.

loans.use: to buy a small automobile.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase shop goods (notebooks, Nido, salt,...) to resell, so as to earn a living

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy ingredients for her husband's food-selling business

loans.name: Anita

texts.es:
Anita como es conocida muy popularmente en el municipio de El Sauce por su carisma y buen corazón, es casada, madre de dos hijas, tiene más de veinte de años de dedicarse a la labor de maestra, la que le ha permitido educar de la mejor manera a sus dos hijas de las cuales una de ellas está estudiando una carrera universitaria y la otra está por culminar la educación secundaria.

Como madre responsable ha tratado de dar lo mejor a ellas para que se preparen profesionalmente y sean mujeres de bien que se defiendan en la vida cuando sus padres les falten.

Por tal motivo está solicitando un crédito a los inversionistas de Kiva para pagar la universidad de su hija en lo que se refiere a aranceles y material didáctico, con el fin de que esto no sea un obstáculo para logre culminar su profesión.

Agradece a estas personas de buen corazón que apoyan a miles de personas sobre todo de escasos recursos a que cumplan sueños que no se puede llevar a cabo con los bajos salarios que se ganan en Nicaragua.
texts.en:
Anita is well-known in the El Sauce municipality for her charisma and her good heart.  She is married, and she has two daughters.

She has been a teacher for over 20 years.  This has allowed her to educate her daughters in the best way.  One of them is studying for a university degree.  The other is about to complete her high school education.

As a responsible mother, she has tried to give them the best in order for them to prepare professionally and so that they become good women who can get by in life when their parents are not there.

That is the reason she is requesting a loan from the Kiva lenders.  She wants the loan to be able to pay for her daughter’s university expenses.  She wants the loan to pay for fees and instructional materials so that these are not obstacles to her daughter getting her degree.

She is grateful to those with  good hearts who support thousands of people, especially those with scarce resources, to fulfill their dreams.  They are not able to do so with the low salaries they earn in Nicaragua.

loans.use: to pay for her daughter's university costs.

loans.name: Gamaliel

texts.fr:
Gamaliel fait partie du groupe Dukure  et est un des victimes de  l’incendie du marché central de Bujumbura. Il est client  de Turame. Il  habite à  Bujumbura. Il est marié à  Cassilde. Ensemble ils ont 3enfants âgés de 1  à  7 ans, dont 1 étudie.
Il a sous sa charge  sa sœur qui étudie.

Il  faisait le commerce des articles divers (sachet, tomates, sel,..)   au marché central de Bujumbura. Il a perdu des marchandises d’une valeur de 2 700 000 FBU(1725,29 $).
De ce fait, ses travaux de construction sont interrompus.

Avec le crédit KIVA qu’il obtient, il va  reconstituer son capital en achetant des  articles divers (sachet, tomates, sel, ..) à revendre pour gagner sa vie.
texts.en:
Gamaliel is part of the group Dukure and is a victim of the fire at the central market of Bujumbura. He a client of Turame. He lives in Bujumbura. He is married to Cassilde. Together they have three children, from 1 to 7 years old, of whom one is a student.

Gamaliel used to do commerce in a variety of goods (packs of water, tomatoes, salt., …) at the central market of Bujumbura. He lost his merchandise, valued at 2,700,00 FBU ($1,725.29). Because of this, his construction work has been interrupted. 

With the KIVA loan he is obtaining, he is going to build back his capital by purchasing various goods (packs of water, tomatoes, salt,…) to resell, so as to earn his living.

loans.use: to purchase various goods (packs of water, tomatoes, salt,...) to resell, so as to earn his living

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Les six  membres du groupe SOUTOURA sont essentiellement de femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 33  ans, et ont en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans les  familles polygamiques à HAMDALLAYE un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso 
Elles sont à leur sixième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Les prêts antérieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
MARIAM, au bout de la photo à droite,  vend de la friperie à dans ce groupe de femmes SOUTOURA. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  une balle de friperie. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso ville.
Elle les revend de façon ambulante et à domicile (Hamdallaye) un des quartiers populaires de la ville  de Sikasso. Sa clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40.000FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The six members of the group SOUTOURA are essentially married women who average 33 years of age and four children each. The women live for the most part in polygamous families in HAMDALLAYE, a working-class district of Sikasso City. 

The women are on their sixth loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to the needs of their customers. The previous loans were correctly paid back.

MARIAM, at the far right in the photo, sells secondhand clothing in this group of women.  She intends to use her loan to purchase a bale of secondhand clothing. She gets her supplies from the big market of Sikasso City.

She resells the merchandise by going door to door and at her home (Hamdallaye, a working-class district in Sikasso City). Her customer base is composed of men and women.  

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 40,000 francs CFA. Part of the profits is used to repay the loan with interest, and the other part is for her savings.

loans.use: to purchase used clothing to sell

loans.name: Jasho Group

texts.en:
Jasho is a group of 16 farmers in Webuye District, represented by Felisters. The group has 14 women and 2 men. Felisters is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to her on credit, consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of sweet potato, millet and sorghum. Felisters first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2010 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer, and to grow enough food for the family.

Felisters reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about two bags of maize per ½ acre, but with her One Acre Fund input loan during Long Rains 2012, she harvested nine bags per 1/2 acre. She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send her children to school and to save for the future. Jasho Group members will each receive input loans of ½ acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total, they will receive inputs for 8 acres of sweet potato, millet and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potato, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Toch's Group

texts.en:
Toch is 33 years old and married. She has been blessed with five children, who currently are studying at the local state school in the area. She manages one hectare each of cassava and rice cultivation. She has been in this business for 15 years, and she earns about 23,600 KHR per day.

Toch has been with VisionFund for five previous loan cycles and has completely repaid her past loans with success. The loans have provided her sufficient decent daily food for her kids and improved her living conditions, at a good pace. Now Toch is in a group of two, to apply for a new loan. She and her co-borrower are seeking the amount of 1,400,000 KHR, each. As group leader, Toch will use her loan portion to buy fertilizer and pesticide, and to pay the plowing fee for preparing her farmland. She has high hopes that she can increase her crop yield and sell her cassava and rice at high prices, to improve her living standard.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide, and to pay the plowing fee for preparing her farmland

loans.name: Sophat

texts.en:
Sophat, 52 years old and married, is a local resident from Ou Reang Ov district of Kampong Cham province. She has four children, one of whom is still in school and counts on her. 

To strive for a living, she does rice cultivation, with support from her husband. To better feed the family, her husband also works for others for a fee, during his spare time. Engaging in the current business for ages, Sophat is able to earn up to KHR 25,000 per day. 

Sophat’s prior loan was her original loan with VisionFund Cambodia (Kiva’s partner). She managed to gain a good yield from her crop, due to the prompt loan, which she has fully repaid. 

Now, Sophat is seeking a new loan to buy a small computer for her son. She hopes that she can supply the study materials for her child in order to boost his knowledge.

loans.use: to buy a small computer for her son.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ou Reang Ov district

loans.name: Jose Luis

texts.es:
José, solicita un nuevo crédito, por la  necesidad de invertir más en la agricultura, en el maiz y pipián. Esta inversión le permitirá comprar insumos agrícolas, plaguicidas, insecticidas, herbicidas.
Con el préstamo anterior logro obtener mejores ingresos y cubrir los gastos del hogar. Las condiciones económicas han mejorado, ya que tuvo un incremento en la productividad.
texts.en:
José is requesting a new loan because he needs to invest more in his corn and pumpkin crops.  This investment will allow him to buy agricultural supplies, pesticides, insecticides, and herbicides.

With the last loan he managed to get better income and to cover the household expenses.  His financial condition has improved because he had an increase in productivity.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies, pesticides, insecticides, and herbicides.

loans.name: Hat's Group

texts.en:
Hat, a 53-year-old married mother of four, lives in a rural area of the Moung Russey district of Battambang province. The family’s main source of income is rice farming, which she has been engaged in for 10 years. Low crop yield is still a main challenge for her family’s business.

Hat has been with VisionFund for two loans, both since repaid and both very important in improving her likelihood. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan of 1,000,000KHR each. As the leader, she will use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes to grow her rice fruitfully so as to expand her rice paddy.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farmland.

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre  membres du groupe KOTOGNOGONTALA sont  des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 36  ans, et ont en moyenne 5 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans les  familles polygamiques à HAMDALLAYE un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso. 
Elles sont à leur huitième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Les prêts antérieures ont été correctement remboursés.
KANDIA, en complet bleu sur la photo, fait le commerce de bazins teintés à dans ce groupe de femmes KOTOGNOGONTALA. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt des pagnes de bazins qu’elle fait teinter. Elle s’approvisionne dans au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et souvent à Bamako la capitale du Mali.
Elle revend teintés sur place à domicile au quartier d’Hamdalaye de Sikasso et souvent sur commande à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’homme au comptant. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30.000 FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The four members of the group KOTOGNOGONTALA are married women who average 36 years of age and five children each. The women live for the most part in polygamous families in HAMDALLAYE, a working-class district of Sikasso City. 

The women are on their 8th loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy the needs of their customers. The previous loans were correctly paid back.

KANDIA, wearing blue in the photo, does commerce in dyed damask fabrics in this group of women. She intends to use her loan to purchase lengths of damask, which she dyes. She gets her supplies from the big market of Sikasso City and often in Bamako, the capital of Mali.

She resells the dyed fabrics locally at her home in the Hamdalaye district in Sikasso and often by special order. Her customer base is composed of men and women paying cash.

She envisions making an average monthly profit of 30,000 francs CFA. Part of the profits is used to repay the loan with interest, and the other part is for her savings.

loans.use: to purchase damask cloth

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy corn, firewood and gas.

loans.name: Segundo Manuel

texts.es:
SEGUNDO tiene 52 años de edad es soltero tiene tres hijos, vive con los hijos y con unos familiares. 

Pertenece a la VRC SAN JUAN BAUTISTA se encuentra formada y creada en la ciudad de Tambanal a una distancia de 40 minutos de la oficina de la cooperatva, La actividad económica es la agricultura, crianza de animales.

SEGUNDO se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, fréjol,además se dedica a la crianza de ganado, pollos y cerdos.
Solicita el crédito para comprar un ganado. Con la ayuda del crédito podrá comprar el ganado. La compra la realizará en Chillanes.

El sueño es mejorar las condiciones de vida. Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta es el mal clima.

En el tiempo libre le gusta disfrutar de las fiestas de la comunidad y del carnaval.
texts.en:
Segundo is 52 years old.  He is single, and he lives with his three children and some other relatives.

He is a member of the community bank San Juan Bautista, which is in the city of Tambanal, which is 40 minutes away from the cooperative farm where he works growing plants and raising animals. He grows corn and beans, and he also raises cows, pigs and chickens.

He is seeking this loan so that he can buy a cow.  He will make the purchase in Chillanes.

His dream is to improve his standard of living.He faces challenges such as bad weather. In his free time he likes to enjoy community festivals and carnivals.

loans.use: to purchase a cow.

loans.name: Norma Lucia

texts.es:
La Sra. Norma tiene viviendo en Piedras Negras desde hace treinta y seis años, es una persona muy responsable y amable que es como la considera su familia y sus vecinas.
En esta ocasión pide apoyo através de KIVA  para cercar su casa, ya que la cerca actual esta muy deteriorada y necesita cambiarla, le preocupa mucho  la inseguridad que se vive hoy en día, quisiera tener más segura a su familia y de igual forma su casa, ya que con mucho esfuerzo ha logrado construirla y es el futuro de sus hijos.
Desea tanto una cerca más grande para que así puedan dormir  más tranquilos. De igual forma tener una mejor calidad de vida y un patrimonio más extenso.
La Sra. Norma trabaja vendiendo productos de belleza de un catalogo reconocido desde hace dos años, siempre ha tratado de superarse para seguir aportando con los gastos de su hogar.
texts.en:
Norma has been living in Piedras Negras for 36 years.  Her family and her neighbors consider her to be a very responsible and kind person.

At this time she is asking for support through Kiva to fence in her house.  The fence that is there now is very rundown, and she needs to change it.  She worries a lot about the lack of safety nowadays.  She would like for her family and her house to be more secure.  She managed to build her house with great effort, and it is her children’s future.

She wishes to have a larger fence in order to be able to sleep more peacefully.  She also wants to have a better quality of life and a more extensive patrimony.

Norma has worked selling beauty products from a well-known catalog for two years.  She has always tried to improve in order to continue contributing to the household expenses.

loans.use: to fence in her house.

loans.name: Reyna Lizzette

texts.es:
Reina,  requiere de un nuevo crédito, por que se encuentra sin ingresos y necesita dinero. Este lo invertirá en la compra de pantalones, blusas, vestidos y ropa interior para su negocio, espera con esta inversion darle estabilidad al negocio.
El préstamo anterior le genero ganancias, porque del mismo negocio cancelo dicho préstamo. Las circunstancias familiares han mejorado un poco y su comercio se mantiene en el mercado, agradece de ante mano le concedan  el crédito porque lo necesita.
texts.en:
Reyna needs a new loan, since she is currently without income and needs to make money.  She will in invest the funds in pants, blouses, dresses and underwear for her business. She hopes that this investment will bring stability to the business.

With her previous loan she was able to make profits with this same business.  Her family circumstances have improved a little, and she has been able to maintain her business, since she was able to get the credit that she needed.

loans.use: to buy pants, blouses, dresses and underwear.

loans.name: Narin's Group

texts.en:
Residing in a rural village in the Dambae district of Cambodia, Narin is 44 years old and married with two children. She and her husband are hard-working farmers who make a living by growing rice. In this business for 10 years, they can earn about 20,000KHR per day to meet the family’s needs.

Narin has been with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund, for three loan cycles, and all loans have been repaid. They have helped her family’s business significantly. Now leading her group to request a loan of 1,000,000KHR each, Narin, who is the leader, will use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her income so as to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farmland.
